White in the day, black in the night. White-black roof with auto slide
4:17

The white roof really brings up a question why roofs everywhere are not white. I guess one reason would be that most roofs in the US (and probably most modern roofs everywhere) are covered in shingles. Those shingles are made out of up to 35% asphalt which gives them a dark color. Singles are probably pretty much impossible to paint. So; we'd have to switch to something else to roof the houses in.

Btw, there IS a benefit to having a dark colored roof during the winter months. Any sun will heat it up and therefor heat up the inside of the house a bit.... but that amount of heat is probably very small. I'm betting the white roof would end up saving MORE money in the long run between heating and cooling the house and be more worth it then a dark roof.

I live on the 2nd story of a house with a dark shingle roof. If it's 80deg F outside on a sunny day, the inside is like 88. I bet a white roof would knock it down to 80deg inside, or maybe even less.

Pardon me, but isn't this whole series a great takeoff on the woke and feminine male, with the climate obsession it's target? Can we ant like humans make a blind bit of difference to the temperature of the planet, compared with that great big ball of nuclear fusion inundating us with heat and radiation? Isn't this whole thing in the realm of climate controlled underpants? I look out the window, I walk across the road, and it is no hotter in summer than it was when I was a kid, and I'm 73 now; the road tar still melted in the heat back then; my country had raging temperatures and droughts back in the 19th century; Carbon dioxide, at 400 to 600ppm, is just 0.04% to 0.06% of the atmosphere, merely a trace gas, just enough for plant survival, which is threatened below 200ppm, or 0.02% of the atmosphere. Predictions of the end have routinely failed since the climate modellers began modelling, and keep on failing. People say we're all going to die, and soon, yet they won't use nuclear power as a solution. very strange, if they are really serious; or is it all an elaborate, exciting little  mind game, darlings? Two of my old friends, a guy and a gal, placed bets with me that all life on earth would be extinguished within 10 years of our bet at the restaurant where we were lunching together, and I thought they were joking. Both very intelligent people. I bet everything would be fine, and they rolled on the floor laughing; they said: You can't possibly collect on this bet, as we will all be dead! That was on 12 of January, 2015; I considered my options carefully, and chose a five course meal with champagne and wine, in an expensive restaurant of my choice, and they thought that even more hilarious. It is now 21 January, 2022; the 12 of January 2025 is just days less than three years off, and it will give me great pleasure to sit there and trim those suckers for the bill! All other things, of course, being equal. Still, I love these Candide like innocents on this channel with their dinky, happily neurotic little plans for saving the planet. Is this some vast, cosmic joke by the powers that be, to give us an alternative religion, and simultaneously and outrageously gouge more taxes out of us, while they laugh at us all for being such honky tonk rubes? Who knows? Just sayin'. And I still don't see the slightest difference in either the weather or the climate, other than the usual, isolated random extremes. And the water in the harbour is still just 1cm higher than it was in the 19th century. Love to you all, and shine on, you crazy diamonds. Geoff. ❤️🍜🌮🧆🥗🍱🍢🍡🥮🍧🍰🎂🍫🍬🍻🍾🥂🥂🥂🥂🍷🍷🍷🍷🙂🤢🤮🤡👍

This video is pointless because you could have put 300 watts worth of solar panels in a mini fridge don't have to do all that extra work where you can put 500 watts worth of pants and have a full size fridge. My RV has three solar panels on the roof and a couple charge controller keep my fridge going all day and night that has a 1/3 size refrigerator with a little freezer in the top corner of it I also have ice cubes

I have two buildings one made out of brick and asphalt shingles the other is All Steel sprinklers on the roof of both buildings and on the hot side walls. On the all steel building I run the sprinklers for one minute every 5 minutes and on the cinder block walls with asphalt shingles I I run the water for 1 minute every 10 minutes and that water comes out of a well putting very cold water on them and then the evaporative cooling takes over after the water heats up. In my shop that's made out of metal 3500 square feet that will drop the temperature on the inside from 110 down to about 75 that building has no insulation. In my house it makes my AC run about 75% less.  I keep my house at 68° in the summertime during the day and 62 degrees at night and before I started using the water the exterior my power bill used to be almost five hundred and it dropped down to less than 200 US dollars in those temperatures are Fahrenheit. I didn't even bother to insulate the shop that works so well

Rather the past of cooling that may become the future of cooling. It's an absorption refrigerator. The Amish still makes large versions that are powered by natural gas or propane and Domestic still makes a model that used kerosene and was popular with cabins that were not hooked up to utilities. For quite some time, RV's and hotels used these refrigerators as they are completely silent as they have no compressor but they have recently fallen out of favor with both of these applications as people now expect refrigerators to be noisy. There are many antique domestics that were used in farm houses but many were used for target practice so may not work too well without doing some plumbing repairs. Amana was actually a religious group that like the Amish made absorption refrigerators and that's how they got started as an appliance manufacturer. I think the Amish ones are branded Diamond or Crystal and they use D cells for the refrigerator light (you need a vent and a natural gas outlet if you want to use one).

Now using Peltier modulE's is what I would consider cheating. You would be better off buying an efficient DC refrigerator at that point as Peltier modules are very inefficient.

The conclusion of "we need smaller fridges" is exactly backwards. We need efficient fridges. The way to build those is using high COP heat pumps, not low efficiency peltier coolers. Larger fridges, kept packed full of food, also have more thermal mass (the exact thing they are trying to achieve by burying their cooler) in the form of the water in the food. Thick insulation is the final piece to the puzzle.

A Peltier element is just a large number of thermo couples. That is just two different metals that generate a milli volt per degree K temperature change. Because this is a natural reaction, it can be reversed. Have a current flowing through it, it will work as a heatpump and therefore get hot on one side and cold on the other side. It's has a very low efficiency.

I think we can do a lot by considering how we build our homes, and how we live in them. I emigrated from Britain to rural Spain, where there are traditional building methods that reduce the need for cooling (and heating in winter.) Other than the white paint you mention,  older homes are built largely from earth and stone, with walls a meter or more thick at ground level, have small windows predominantly on the north-facing side of the house and may have internal rooms with no window at all. They have an empty upper story, used for storage, drying laundry etc. while the family lives on the lower story or stories. (People who have modernised to make use of this space often maintain a bedroom on the lower floor for the hottest weather.) The main cooking area, and often the bathroom as well, is separate from the body of the house (although there may also be a winter kitchen, often a later addition.) These ideas may not be all be practicable, especially in cities, but they are astonishingly effective. My neighbour's ancestors really knew something about building for the climate!

Hate being "that guy" but 50 C is not "half way to boiling" because 0 C is an arbitrary zero, mathematically speaking. You wouldn't say 323 K (50 C) is halfway to 373 K (100 C). To nerd it up a bit more, it's because temp in C is an internal level variable (so, + or - math only) but temp in K is ratio (x and /, as well as +/-). That said, really enjoying the series.
